docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Paul Krugman (column, July 9) notes that one objection to John Kerry's health care plan is that ''it falls far short of the comprehensive overhaul our health care system really needs.'' I agree. But such an overhaul is extremely unlikely, even in the case of regime change at the top. I'd be happy with the Kerry plan as a solid first step. NATHANIEL DERBY Seattle, July 9, 2004

headline.main: Kerry's Health Plan: A Good First Step?

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Afghan Leader Calls Militias Biggest Threat President Hamid Karzai of Afghanistan said that private armies loyal to warlords were now greater threats than the Taliban insurgency and that they were at least partly responsible for the delay in parliamentary elections. Mr. Karzai also said he was abandoning his gentle approach in trying to pressure the country's private armies to disarm. A1 Three U.S. Soldiers Killed Three American soldiers were killed in attacks in Iraq, two by a roadside bomb near Samarra and one by a separate roadside bomb. A10

docs.lead_paragraph: Going door to door as part of an innovative effort to expand the labor movement's reach, Natasha Skorupa encountered some hurdles that union organizers rarely face. At one house with a ''beware of the dog'' sign on the chain-link fence, she debated at length whether or not to enter the yard, while at others, homeowners slammed the door because they were in the middle of dinner.

headline.main: Labor Federation Looks Beyond Unions for Supporters

docs.abstract: AFL-CIO is developing Working America, advocacy group to lobby alongside labor unions on various issues such as minimum wage and overtime; has recruited 400,000 members since 2003, and is adding 20,000 per week; percentage of workers in labor unions has dropped to 12.9 percent from high of 35 percent in 1950's; Service Employees International is making similar effort to develop Purple Ocean group of labor sympathizers; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WE endow our presidents with mythical power, holding them responsible for the health of the economy. But any president's influence over the twists and turns of the complicated American economy is inevitably less than is advertised. George W. Bush is not to be blamed for the recession that overtook the country two months after his inauguration. Nor is he the author of the upturn that seemed so promising in the spring. Now the economy may be weakening again, which suggests that, if he became president, John F. Kerry would preside over a downturn during his opening months in office, followed, eventually, by an upturn.
docs.abstract: Economic View column on how economy's performance is beyond a president's control; says George W Bush is not be blamed for recession that overtook country two months after his inauguration; holds nor is he author of upturn that seemed promising in spring; says economy may be weakening again, which suggests that, if he became president, John F Kerry would preside over downturn during his opening months in office, followed, eventually, by upturn; says both would be beyond his control, or any president's, although Kerry would be blamed for downturn and praised for rebound; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: EVERY presidential ticket is a snapshot of a party, a particular political moment, a particular political need. Often, it shows politicians scrambling to pull together various regions or ideological wings of a party, like Franklin D. Roosevelt paired with the conservative Texan John Nance Garner, the speaker of the House, in 1932. Sometimes, the politicians are trying to reflect (and capitalize on) a major social or demographic change -- notably Walter F. Mondale, hoping to galvanize his decidedly uphill campaign by naming a woman, Geraldine A. Ferraro, as his running-mate in 1984.

headline.main: The Nation: Class Matters; Money, Politics, And Four Rich Men

docs.abstract: John Kerry's selection of John Edwards to be his running mate signals extent to which Democratic presidential campaign will revolve around class--which party represents aspirations, values and economic interests of hard-working middle America; Edwards is fourth white male millionaire to join national tickets, but there are class differences even among millionaires; he is son of millworker, first generation in his family to go to college, and he made his own fortune as trial lawyer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Your June 20 article about residential flooding problems along the Saw Mill River and one of its tributaries illustrates the necessity for watershed-wide planning and for communities all along the river to work together in developing wise land use practices. Upstream modifications to the flood plain, such as the filling in of a wetland, the addition of a parking lot or some other high-impact development too close to the stream channel, can cause problems downriver. Water needs to go somewhere, and when it storms, the rain can either seep into the ground, or, finding surfaces it cannot penetrate, such as concrete roadways and impervious rooftops, will make its way to the river, carrying debris, road salt, automotive chemicals, fertilizers, pesticides and other forms of water pollution it gathers along its path.

headline.main: When the Saw Mill River Floods

docs.lead_paragraph: Senator John Kerry's representatives avoided a Democratic Party platform fight over Iraq on Saturday by persuading platform committee delegates supporting Representative Dennis J. Kucinich to withdraw their proposals for a quick withdrawal of United States combat troops from Iraq. Instead, the committee agreed to present a platform to the Democratic convention in Boston this month that reflects Mr. Kerry's position. The statement of party principles promises to seek help from Western allies and Arab countries in bringing Iraq under control but says nothing about how to accomplish that goal.

headline.main: Kerry Team Settles Dispute With Kucinich Delegates Over Iraq

docs.abstract: Sen John Kerry's representatives convince platform committee delegates supporting Rep Dennis J Kucinich to withdraw proposals for quick exit from Iraq; party platform will pledge to withdraw troops when appropriate so that necessary military support for Iraqi government will not be seen as continuation of American occupation; Iowa Gov Tom Vilsack says it is clear troops must stay until Iraq is stabilized; platform recognizes need for international partners (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: An article last Sunday about the costs of prescription and over-the-counter medications referred incorrectly to the allergy drug Zyrtec. It is available only by prescription.

docs.lead_paragraph: The state paid a health insurer for poor children $20 million in unearned fees by failing to supervise the contract properly, a government study said. The state auditor's office faulted the Health and Human Services Commission for lax oversight and the billing and management of the underwriter, part of Hannover Re, Clarendon National. Clarendon said it had no comment. The agency said Community Health Solutions would take over on Sept. 1 under a contract with tighter controls. The program has dropped almost 150,000 children because of budget cuts and higher deductibles. Steve Barnes(NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Southwest: Texas: Insurer Replaces Company Under Cloud

docs.abstract: Texas Auditor's Office says state paid Clarendon National, health insurer for poor children, $20 million in unearned fees because of failure to supervise contract properly (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the four years before he joined the Senate in 1999, John Edwards made a total of nearly $27 million as a personal injury lawyer who won a string of multimillion-dollar jury verdicts and settlements. The Kerry-Edwards Democratic presidential campaign released Mr. Edwards's income figures in a statement yesterday in response to questions about the taxes he paid after he created a tax shelter in 1995.

headline.kicker: THE 2004 CAMPAIGN: THE NORTH CAROLINA SENATOR

docs.abstract: Kerry-Edwards Democratic presidential campaign releases Sen John Edwards income figures in response to questions about taxes he paid after he created tax shelter in 1995; Edwards, in four years before he joined Senate in 1999, made nearly $27 million as personal injury lawyer; he paid $9,353,448 in federal taxes on his income, but shelter allowed him to avoid paying $591,112 in Medicare tax; Edwards has declined to release his full tax filings on annual basis, and his earnings as trial lawyer have been matter of speculation until now; photo (M)
